title: Basic Usage Example
intro: On this page we will cover a very basic example of a Lifecycle in action. We have set up a small Enterprise structure and have created a Lifecycle. (If you don't know how to create a Lifecycle, please refer to our page in the Enterprise Setup section, Template Lifecycle Definition

blocks.content: It is recommended that you are familiar with how to run Templates on the web, view & edit Templates in the Template editor and are familiar with the Inbox before trying to follow along with this example.

Assuming that you have already set up your Enterprise structure, have more than a single Member and have created a Lifecycle, let's now run through a basic scenario to see how Lifecycle-based Template Edition works. If you want to run through the example yourself make sure to have the following:

points.text: A Lifecycle set up in the same Group as these accounts
Each Member should have a different Role assigned that covers the Lifecycle stages

blocks.caption: We've created a new Template and made sure to give it a name. The Template itself is empty since we will be submitting it to an 'Author' Role Member to fill in the detail. Clicking on 'Submit' we are presented with the Submission window.

When submitting the Template, a user must select the Lifecycle to submit it to. This can be done in the dropdown show here. Once submitted the user will see a small notification to confirm the successful submission.

In our example, we have set up an Initiate stage which specifies that the Template is required to go through approval by a 'Product Manager' Role to start the Lifecycle process for the Template. At this point therefore a Member with the 'Product Manager' Role picks up the Task from their Dashboard by clicking 'View'.
Our 'Product Manager' Member approves of the need for this type of Template therefore he clicks the Lifecycle action 'Initiate'. Here we are confirming this action.
The Task is opened in the Template Editor and allows the 'Author' Member to continue to add more detail to the Template definition structure.

Once the Author is happy with the Template structure, they can then submit the Template to the next stage, Review. This is achieved by clicking the Review action button in the top corner (this area is reserved for all Lifecycle actions, showing only those that are relevant for the stage that the Template is in.
Upon submission, the user is asked to confirm their choice. As before, the user will receive a notification confirming the submission.

For those Members with reviewing Roles, the Task will show up in their Inboxes and display the correct information. Like the previous Tasks, the user clicks 'View' to open the Template in the Template Editor.

Reviewing Templates displays a read-only version of the Template which gives a full overview of the entire structure without the ability to add or delete Steps from the Template. A user happy with the Template can use the appropriate Lifecycle actions to move the Template to the next stage.

Depending on your Lifecycle stage setup, you may pass through many review stages before a final review stage allowing users with the correct Role to finally approve the Template and publish it to the Enterprise. Here, we show the Inbox Task relating to the stage.
Much like the previous stages, and since this is also considered a Review stage, once a user has opened the Task they are given a read-only view of the Template.

Once the Template has been approved and Published you will see the Template in your Templates list (and in the All Enterprise Templates list) display as you can see here. The Published flag indicates it has been approved by Lifecycle and is therefore fit for use.
